nodes.name: CIS Critical Security Controls
nodes.description: A prescriptive, prioritized, and simplified set of best practices that you can use to strengthen your cybersecurity posture.

nodes.name: Documentation
nodes.description: Policies, processes, procedures, plans, diagrams, and other written material (physical or digital).

nodes.name: Software
nodes.description: Operating systems and applications, including services, libraries, APIs, and firmware.

nodes.name: Network
nodes.description: Interconnected devices that exchange data, including physical/virtual infrastructure and architecture.

nodes.name: Users
nodes.description: Employees, contractors, service providers, and authorized users including administrator and service accounts.

nodes.name: Data
nodes.description: Digital data stored, transferred, and processed by enterprise assets, including sensitive, log, and physical data.

nodes.name: Applications
nodes.description: Software programs running on top of an operating system, including web, database, cloud, and mobile apps.

nodes.name: Devices
nodes.description: Enterprise assets (data processing and storage), end-user devices, portable/mobile devices, servers, IoT, and network devices.

nodes.name: Penetration Testing
nodes.description: Test the effectiveness and resiliency of enterprise assets through identifying and exploiting weaknesses in controls.

Perform periodic red team exercises to test organizational readiness to identify and stop attacks or to respond quickly and effectively. Red team exercises must be conducted through a qualified party.
nodes.title: Perform Periodic Red Team Exercises

nodes.name: IG3
nodes.description: For enterprises with specialized security experts, sensitive data subject to high regulatory oversight, and need to abate targeted attacks.
nodes.title: Advanced Enterprise Security

nodes.name: Detect
nodes.description: Develop and implement appropriate activities to identify the occurrence of a cybersecurity event.
Validate security measures after each penetration test. If deemed necessary, modify rulesets and capabilities to detect the techniques used by testers.
nodes.title: Validate Security Measures

nodes.name: Protect
nodes.description: Develop and implement appropriate safeguards to ensure delivery of critical services.

Perform periodic internal penetration tests based on program requirements, no less than annually. The testing may be clear box or opaque box. Penetration testing requires specialized skills and experience and must be conducted through a qualified party.
nodes.title: Perform Periodic Internal Penetration Tests

nodes.name: IG2
nodes.description: For enterprises with dedicated IT/Security staff, supporting multiple departments with differing risk profiles and regulatory burdens.
nodes.title: Enterprise Security

nodes.description: Perform periodic external penetration tests based on program requirements, no less than annually. External penetration testing must include enterprise and environmental reconnaissance to detect exploitable information. Penetration testing requires specialized skills and experience and must be conducted through a qualified party. The testing may be clear box or opaque box.
nodes.title: Perform Periodic External Penetration Tests

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a penetration testing program appropriate to the size, complexity, industry, and maturity of the enterprise. Penetration testing program characteristics include scope, such as network, web application, Application Programming Interface (API), hosted services, and physical premise controls; frequency; limitations, such as acceptable hours, and excluded attack types; point of contact information; remediation, such as how findings will be routed internally; and retrospective requirements.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Penetration Testing Program

nodes.name: Govern
nodes.description: Establish and monitor the organization’s cybersecurity risk management strategy, expectations, and policy.

nodes.name: Incident Response Management
nodes.description: Establish a program to develop and maintain an incident response capability to prepare, detect, and quickly respond to an attack.

Establish and maintain security incident thresholds. The thresholds should differentiate between an event and an incident. Review and update thresholds annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain Security Incident Thresholds

nodes.name: Recover
nodes.description: Develop and implement appropriate activities to maintain plans for resilience and to restore any capabilities or services that were impaired.
Conduct post-incident reviews. The reviews should identify lessons learned and opportunities for improvement. Conduct reviews after each major incident.
nodes.title: Conduct Post-Incident Reviews

nodes.description: Conduct routine incident response exercises. Example exercises include: tabletop exercises and simulations. Conduct exercises annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Conduct Routine Incident Response Exercises

nodes.description: Define mechanisms for communicating during incident response. Example mechanisms include: out-of-band communication, secure messaging apps, and encrypted email. Review and update mechanisms annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Define Mechanisms for Communicating During Incident Response

nodes.name: Respond
nodes.description: Develop and implement appropriate activities to take action regarding a detected cybersecurity incident.

Assign key roles and responsibilities for incident response. Example roles include: incident commander, scribe, and public relations. Review and update roles and responsibilities annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Assign Key Roles and Responsibilities

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an incident response process for third-party service providers. The process should include reporting requirements and a communications plan. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Incident Response Process for

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an enterprise process for reporting incidents. The process should include whom to report to and the method of reporting. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Enterprise Process for Reporting

nodes.name: IG1
nodes.description: Foundational set of cyber defense Safeguards that every enterprise should apply to guard against the most common attacks.
nodes.title: Essential Cyber Hygiene

nodes.description: Establish and maintain contact information for reporting security incidents. The contact information should be easily accessible to all workforce members. Review and update contact information annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain Contact Information for Reporting

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an incident response process. In the process, address roles and responsibilities, compliance requirements, and a communications plan. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Incident Response Process

nodes.name: Application Software Security
nodes.description: Manage the security life cycle of in-house developed, hosted, or acquired software to prevent, detect, and remediate security weaknesses.
Conduct threat modeling. Conduct threat modeling annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Conduct Threat Modeling

nodes.description: Conduct application penetration testing. Conduct testing annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Conduct Application Penetration Testing

nodes.description: Implement code-level security checks. Example checks include: static application security testing (SAST), dynamic application security testing (DAST), and interactive application security testing (IAST).
nodes.title: Implement Code-Level Security Checks

nodes.description: Leverage vetted modules or services for application security components. Example components include: identity management, encryption, and logging.
nodes.title: Leverage Vetted Modules or Services for Application Security

nodes.description: Apply secure design principles in application architectures. Example principles include: least privilege, defense in depth, and fail secure.
nodes.title: Apply Secure Design Principles in Application Architectures

nodes.description: Train developers in application security concepts and secure coding. Example topics include: OWASP Top 10, SANS Top 25, and secure coding standards. Conduct training annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Train Developers in Application Security Concepts and Secure

nodes.description: Separate production and non-production systems. Example implementations include: separate networks, separate accounts, and separate storage.
nodes.title: Separate Production and Non-Production Systems

nodes.description: Use standard hardening configuration templates for application infrastructure. Example templates include: Center for Internet Security (CIS) Benchmarks and Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA) Security Technical Implementation Guides (STIGs).
nodes.title: Use Standard Hardening Configuration Templates for Application

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a severity rating system for application vulnerabilities. The rating system should be based on the risk to the enterprise and the likelihood of exploitation. Review and update the rating system annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Severity Rating System for Application

nodes.description: Use up-to-date and trusted third-party software components. Example components include: libraries, frameworks, and APIs. When possible, choose components that are actively maintained and have a known security track record.
nodes.title: Use Up-to-Date and Trusted Third-Party Software Components

nodes.description: Establish and manage an inventory of third-party software components. The inventory is to list all known third-party software components, including versioning. Review and update the inventory monthly, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Establish and Manage an Inventory of Third-Party Software

nodes.name: Identify
nodes.description: Understand the organization to manage cybersecurity risk to systems, people, assets, data, and capabilities.
Perform root cause analysis on security vulnerabilities. Review root cause analysis results annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Perform Root Cause Analysis on Security Vulnerabilities

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a process to accept and address software vulnerabilities, including reporting, prioritization, and remediation. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Process to Accept and Address

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a secure application development process. In the process, address secure coding practices, security testing, and developer training. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Application Development Process

nodes.name: Service Provider Management
nodes.description: Develop a process to evaluate service providers who hold sensitive data or are responsible for critical IT platforms or processes.
Securely decommission service providers. Example requirements include: user and service account deactivation, data disposal, and termination of network connections.
nodes.title: Securely Decommission Service Providers

nodes.description: Monitor service providers. Monitoring consideration may include: service level agreements (SLAs), third-party risk management (TPRM) tools, and news alerts. Review monitoring results quarterly.
nodes.title: Monitor Service Providers

nodes.description: Assess service providers. Assessment consideration may include: SOC 2 reports, ISO certifications, and independent audits. Assess service providers prior to engagement and annually thereafter.
nodes.title: Assess Service Providers

nodes.description: Ensure service provider contracts include security requirements. Example requirements include: minimum security controls, incident notification, data encryption, and data disposal. Review service provider contracts annually to ensure contracts are not missing security requirements.
nodes.title: Ensure Service Provider Contracts Include Security Requirements

nodes.description: Classify service providers. Classification consideration may include: data sensitivity, data volume, availability requirements, applicable regulations, and inherent risk. Review and update classification annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Classify Service Providers

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a service provider management policy. Ensure the policy addresses the classification, inventory, assessment, monitoring, and decommissioning of service providers. Review and update the policy annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Service Provider Management Policy

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an inventory of service providers. The inventory is to list all known service providers, include classification(s), and designate an enterprise contact for each service provider. Review and update the inventory annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Service Providers

nodes.name: Security Awareness and Skills Training
nodes.description: Establish and maintain a security awareness program to influence behavior among the workforce to be security conscious and properly skilled.
Conduct role-specific security awareness and skills training. Example topics include secure system administration, secure coding, and verification of security controls.
nodes.title: Conduct Role-Specific Security Awareness and Skills Training

nodes.description: Train workforce members on the dangers of connecting to and transmitting enterprise data over insecure networks.
nodes.title: Train Workforce Members on the Dangers of Connecting to

nodes.description: Train workforce members on how to identify and report if their enterprise assets are missing updates.
nodes.title: Train Workforce Members on How to Identify and Report

nodes.description: Train workforce members on recognizing and reporting security incidents. Example topics include the “See Something, Say Something” mindset and how to report an incident.
nodes.title: Train Workforce Members on Recognizing and Reporting Security

nodes.description: Train workforce members on causes of unintentional data exposure. Example topics include mis-delivery of data and losing a portable end-user device.
nodes.title: Train Workforce Members on Causes of Unintentional Data

nodes.description: Train workforce members on data handling best practices. Example topics include data classification, storage, transmission, and disposal.
nodes.title: Train Workforce Members on Data Handling Best Practices

nodes.description: Train workforce members on authentication best practices. Example topics include MFA, password composition, and credential management.
nodes.title: Train Workforce Members on Authentication Best Practices

nodes.description: Train workforce members to recognize social engineering attacks, such as phishing, pre-texting, and tailgating.
nodes.title: Train Workforce Members to Recognize Social Engineering Attacks

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a security awareness program. The purpose of a security awareness program is to educate the enterprise’s workforce on how to interact with enterprise assets and data in a secure manner. Conduct training at hire and, at a minimum, annually. Review and update content annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Security Awareness Program

nodes.name: Network Monitoring and Defense
nodes.description: Operate processes and tooling to establish and maintain comprehensive network monitoring and defense against security threats.
Perform application layer filtering. Example implementations include a filtering proxy, protocol anomaly detection, or an application firewall.
nodes.title: Perform Application Layer Filtering

nodes.description: Deploy port-level access control. Port-level access control requires 802.1x, or equivalent network access control protocols, such as certificates, to mitigate the risk of an unauthorized device connecting to the network.
nodes.title: Deploy Port-Level Access Control

nodes.description: Deploy a network intrusion prevention solution, where appropriate. Example implementations include the use of a Network Intrusion Prevention System (NIPS) or equivalent cloud-native service.
nodes.title: Deploy a Network Intrusion Prevention Solution

nodes.description: Deploy a host-based intrusion prevention solution on enterprise assets, where appropriate and/or supported. Example implementations include use of an Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) client or host-based IPS agent.
nodes.title: Deploy a Host-Based Intrusion Prevention Solution

nodes.description: Collect network traffic flow logs, where appropriate.
nodes.title: Collect Network Traffic Flow Logs

nodes.description: Manage access control for remote assets. Example implementations include a SASE, or similar remote access technology, to centralize, manage, and control network access.
nodes.title: Manage Access Control for Remote Assets

nodes.description: Perform traffic filtering between network segments, where appropriate.
nodes.title: Perform Traffic Filtering Between Network Segments

nodes.description: Deploy a network intrusion detection solution on enterprise assets, where appropriate. Example implementations include the use of a Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) or equivalent cloud-native service.
nodes.title: Deploy a Network Intrusion Detection Solution

nodes.description: Deploy a host-based intrusion detection solution on enterprise assets, where appropriate and/or supported.
nodes.title: Deploy a Host-Based Intrusion Detection Solution

nodes.description: Centralize security event alerting across enterprise assets for log correlation and analysis. Best practice implementation requires the use of a SIEM, which includes vendor-defined alerts.
nodes.title: Centralize Security Event Alerting

nodes.name: Network Infrastructure Management
nodes.description: Establish, implement, and actively manage network devices to prevent attackers from exploiting vulnerable network services.

Establish and maintain dedicated computing resources for all administrative work. Conduct administrative activities on dedicated administrative workstations, where supported, or as a segregated/isolated environment from the user's primary workspace.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain Dedicated Computing Resources

nodes.description: Ensure remote devices utilize a VPN, SASE, or similar remote access technology and are connecting to an enterprise’s AAA infrastructure.
nodes.title: Ensure Remote Devices Utilize a VPN and are Connecting to

nodes.description: Use secure network management and communication protocols. Example implementations include 802.1X, Wi-Fi Protected Access 2 (WPA2) Enterprise or greater, and VPN/SASE.
nodes.title: Use of Secure Network Management and Communication Protocols

nodes.description: Centralize network authentication, Authorization, and Accounting (AAA).
nodes.title: Centralize Network Authentication

nodes.description: Establish and maintain architecture diagrams and other network documentation. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain Architecture Diagrams

nodes.description: Securely manage network infrastructure. Example implementations include version-controlled IaC and accessing administrative interfaces over secure network protocols, such as SSH and HTTPS. Do not use insecure management protocols, such as Telnet and HTTP, unless operationally essential.
nodes.title: Securely Manage Network Infrastructure

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a secure network architecture. A secure network architecture must address segmentation, least privilege, and availability, at a minimum. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Network Architecture

nodes.description: Ensure network infrastructure is kept up-to-date. Example implementations include running the latest stable release of software and/or using currently supported network-as-a-service (NaaS) offerings. Review software versions monthly, or more frequently, to verify support.
nodes.title: Ensure Network Infrastructure is Up-to-Date

nodes.name: Data Recovery
nodes.description: Establish and maintain data recovery practices sufficient to restore in-scope enterprise assets to a pre-incident and trusted state.
Test data recovery at least annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Test Data Recovery

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an isolated instance of recovery data. Example implementations include version control, offline backup, or offsite backup.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Isolated Instance of Recovery Data

nodes.description: Protect recovery data with equivalent controls to the original data. Reference encryption or data separation, based on requirements.
nodes.title: Protect Recovery Data

nodes.description: Perform automated backups of in-scope enterprise assets. Run backups weekly, or more frequently, based on the sensitivity of the data.
nodes.title: Perform Automated Backups

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a documented data recovery process that includes detailed backup procedures. In the process, address the scope of data recovery activities, recovery prioritization, and the security of backup data. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Data Recovery Process

nodes.name: Malware Defenses
nodes.description: Prevent or control the installation, spread, and execution of malicious applications, code, or scripts on enterprise assets.
Use behavior-based anti-malware software.
nodes.title: Use Behavior-Based Anti-Malware Software

nodes.description: Centrally manage anti-malware software.
nodes.title: Centrally Manage Anti-Malware Software

nodes.description: Enable anti-exploitation features on enterprise assets and software, where possible, such as Microsoft® Data Execution Prevention (DEP), Windows® Defender Exploit Guard (WDEG), or Apple® System Integrity Protection (SIP) and Gatekeeper™.
nodes.title: Enable Anti-Exploitation Features

nodes.description: Configure anti-malware software to automatically scan removable media.
nodes.title: Configure Automatic Anti-Malware Scanning of Removable Media

nodes.description: Disable autorun and autoplay auto-execute functionality for removable media.
nodes.title: Disable Autorun and Autoplay for Removable Media

nodes.description: Configure automatic updates for anti-malware signature files on all enterprise assets.
nodes.title: Configure Automatic Anti-Malware Signature Updates

nodes.description: Deploy and maintain anti-malware software on all enterprise assets.
nodes.title: Deploy and Maintain Anti-Malware Software

nodes.name: Email and Web Browser Protections
nodes.description: Improve protections and detections of threats from email and web vectors, as these are opportunities for attackers to manipulate human behavior.
Deploy and maintain email server anti-malware protections, such as attachment scanning and/ or sandboxing.
nodes.title: Deploy and Maintain Email Server Anti-Malware Protections

nodes.description: Block unnecessary file types attempting to enter the enterprise’s email gateway.
nodes.title: Block Unnecessary File Types

nodes.description: To lower the chance of spoofed or modified emails from valid domains, implement DMARC policy and verification, starting with implementing the Sender Policy Framework (SPF) and the DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) standards.
nodes.title: Implement DMARC

nodes.description: Restrict, either through uninstalling or disabling, any unauthorized or unnecessary browser or email client plugins, extensions, and add-on applications.
nodes.title: Restrict Unnecessary or Unauthorized Browser and Email

nodes.description: Enforce and update network-based URL filters to limit an enterprise asset from connecting to potentially malicious or unapproved websites. Example implementations include category- based filtering, reputation-based filtering, or through the use of block lists. Enforce filters for all enterprise assets.
nodes.title: Maintain and Enforce Network-Based URL Filters

nodes.description: Use DNS filtering services on all end-user devices, including remote and on-premises assets, to block access to known malicious domains.
nodes.title: Use DNS Filtering Services

nodes.description: Ensure only fully supported browsers and email clients are allowed to execute in the enterprise, only using the latest version of browsers and email clients provided through the vendor.
nodes.title: Ensure Use of Only Fully Supported Browsers and Email Clients

nodes.name: Audit Log Management
nodes.description: Collect, alert, review, and retain audit logs of events that could help detect, understand, or recover from an attack.
Collect service provider logs, where supported. Example implementations include collecting authentication and authorization events, data creation and disposal events, and user management events.
nodes.title: Collect Service Provider Logs

nodes.description: Conduct reviews of audit logs to detect anomalies or abnormal events that could indicate a potential threat. Conduct reviews on a weekly, or more frequent, basis.
nodes.title: Conduct Audit Log Reviews

nodes.description: Retain audit logs across enterprise assets for a minimum of 90 days.
nodes.title: Retain Audit Logs

nodes.description: Centralize, to the extent possible, audit log collection and retention across enterprise assets in accordance with the documented audit log management process. Example implementations primarily include leveraging a SIEM tool to centralize multiple log sources.
nodes.title: Centralize Audit Logs

nodes.description: Collect command-line audit logs. Example implementations include collecting audit logs from PowerShell®, BASH™, and remote administrative terminals.
nodes.title: Collect Command-Line Audit Logs

nodes.description: Collect URL request audit logs on enterprise assets, where appropriate and supported.
nodes.title: Collect URL Request Audit Logs

nodes.description: Collect DNS query audit logs on enterprise assets, where appropriate and supported.
nodes.title: Collect DNS Query Audit Logs

nodes.description: Configure detailed audit logging for enterprise assets containing sensitive data. Include event source, date, username, timestamp, source addresses, destination addresses, and other useful elements that could assist in a forensic investigation.
nodes.title: Collect Detailed Audit Logs

nodes.description: Standardize time synchronization. Configure at least two synchronized time sources across enterprise assets, where supported.
nodes.title: Standardize Time Synchronization

nodes.description: Ensure that logging destinations maintain adequate storage to comply with the enterprise’s audit log management process.
nodes.title: Ensure Adequate Audit Log Storage

nodes.description: Collect audit logs. Ensure that logging, per the enterprise’s audit log management process, has been enabled across enterprise assets.
nodes.title: Collect Audit Logs

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a documented audit log management process that defines the enterprise’s logging requirements. At a minimum, address the collection, review, and retention of audit logs for enterprise assets. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Audit Log Management Process

nodes.name: Continuous Vulnerability Management
nodes.description: Develop a plan to continuously assess and track vulnerabilities on all enterprise assets within the enterprise's infrastructure.
Remediate detected vulnerabilities in software through processes and tooling on a monthly, or more frequent, basis, based on the remediation process.
nodes.title: Remediate Detected Vulnerabilities

nodes.description: Perform automated vulnerability scans of externally-exposed enterprise assets. Perform scans on a monthly, or more frequent, basis.
nodes.title: Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Externally-Exposed

nodes.description: Perform automated vulnerability scans of internal enterprise assets on a quarterly, or more frequent, basis. Conduct both authenticated and unauthenticated scans.
nodes.title: Perform Automated Vulnerability Scans of Internal Enterprise Assets

nodes.description: Perform application updates on enterprise assets through automated patch management on a monthly, or more frequent, basis.
nodes.title: Perform Automated Application Patch Management

nodes.description: Perform operating system updates on enterprise assets through automated patch management on a monthly, or more frequent, basis.
nodes.title: Perform Automated Operating System Patch Management

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a risk-based remediation strategy documented in a remediation process, with monthly, or more frequent, reviews.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Remediation Process

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a documented vulnerability management process for enterprise assets. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Vulnerability Management Process

nodes.name: Access Control Management
nodes.description: Use processes and tools to create, assign, manage, and revoke access credentials and privileges for user, administrator, and service accounts.

Define and maintain role-based access control, through determining and documenting the access rights necessary for each role within the enterprise to successfully carry out its assigned duties. Perform access control reviews of enterprise assets to validate that all privileges are authorized, on a recurring schedule at a minimum annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Define and Maintain Role-Based Access Control

nodes.description: Centralize access control for all enterprise assets through a directory service or SSO provider, where supported.
nodes.title: Centralize Access Control

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an inventory of the enterprise’s authentication and authorization systems, including those hosted on-site or at a remote service provider. Review and update the inventory, at a minimum, annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Authentication and

nodes.description: Require MFA for all administrative access accounts, where supported, on all enterprise assets, whether managed on-site or through a service provider.
nodes.title: Require MFA for Administrative Access

nodes.description: Require MFA for remote network access.
nodes.title: Require MFA for Remote Network Access

nodes.description: Require all externally-exposed enterprise or third-party applications to enforce MFA, where supported. Enforcing MFA through a directory service or SSO provider is a satisfactory implementation of this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Require MFA for Externally-Exposed Applications

nodes.description: Establish and follow a process, preferably automated, for revoking access to enterprise assets, through disabling accounts immediately upon termination, rights revocation, or role change of a user. Disabling accounts, instead of deleting accounts, may be necessary to preserve audit trails.
nodes.title: Establish an Access Revoking Process

nodes.description: Establish and follow a documented process, preferably automated, for granting access to enterprise assets upon new hire or role change of a user.
nodes.title: Establish an Access Granting Process

nodes.name: Account Management
nodes.description: Use processes and tools to assign and manage authorization to credentials for user accounts, including administrator and service accounts.
Centralize account management through a directory or identity service.
nodes.title: Centralize Account Management

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an inventory of service accounts. The inventory, at a minimum, must contain department owner, review date, and purpose. Perform service account reviews to validate that all active accounts are authorized, on a recurring schedule at a minimum quarterly, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Service Accounts

nodes.description: Restrict administrator privileges to dedicated administrator accounts on enterprise assets. Conduct general computing activities, such as internet browsing, email, and productivity suite use, from the user’s primary, non-privileged account.
nodes.title: Restrict Administrator Privileges to Dedicated Administrator Accounts

nodes.description: Delete or disable any dormant accounts after a period of 45 days of inactivity, where supported.
nodes.title: Disable Dormant Accounts

nodes.description: Use unique passwords for all enterprise assets. Best practice implementation includes, at a minimum, an 8-character password for accounts using Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) and a 14-character password for accounts not using MFA.
nodes.title: Use Unique Passwords

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an inventory of all accounts managed in the enterprise. The inventory must at a minimum include user, administrator, and service accounts. The inventory, at a minimum, should contain the person’s name, username, start/stop dates, and department. Validate that all active accounts are authorized, on a recurring schedule at a minimum quarterly, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain an Inventory of Accounts

nodes.name: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
nodes.description: Establish and maintain the secure configuration of enterprise assets and software.

Ensure separate enterprise workspaces are used on mobile end-user devices, where supported. Example implementations include using an Apple® Configuration Profile or Android™ Work Profile to separate enterprise applications and data from personal applications and data.
nodes.title: Separate Enterprise Workspaces on Mobile End-User Devices

nodes.description: Remotely wipe enterprise data from enterprise-owned portable end-user devices when deemed appropriate such as lost or stolen devices, or when an individual no longer supports the enterprise.
nodes.title: Enforce Remote Wipe Capability on Portable End-User Devices

nodes.description: Enforce automatic device lockout following a predetermined threshold of local failed authentication attempts on portable end-user devices, where supported. For laptops, do not allow more than 20 failed authentication attempts; for tablets and smartphones, no more than 10 failed authentication attempts. Example implementations include Microsoft® InTune Device Lock and Apple® Configuration Profile maxFailedAttempts.
nodes.title: Enforce Automatic Device Lockout on Portable End-User Devices

nodes.description: Configure trusted DNS servers on network infrastructure. Example implementations include configuring network devices to use enterprise-controlled DNS servers and/or reputable externally accessible DNS servers.
nodes.title: Configure Trusted DNS Servers on Enterprise Assets

nodes.description: Uninstall or disable unnecessary services on enterprise assets and software, such as an unused file sharing service, web application module, or service function.
nodes.title: Uninstall or Disable Unnecessary Services on Enterprise Assets

nodes.description: Manage default accounts on enterprise assets and software, such as root, administrator, and other pre-configured vendor accounts. Example implementations can include: disabling default accounts or making them unusable.
nodes.title: Manage Default Accounts on Enterprise Assets and Software

nodes.description: Securely manage enterprise assets and software. Example implementations include managing configuration through version-controlled Infrastructure-as-Code (IaC) and accessing administrative interfaces over secure network protocols, such as Secure Shell (SSH) and Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS). Do not use insecure management protocols, such as Telnet (Teletype Network) and HTTP, unless operationally essential.
nodes.title: Securely Manage Enterprise Assets and Software

nodes.description: Implement and manage a host-based firewall or port-filtering tool on end-user devices, with a default-deny rule that drops all traffic except those services and ports that are explicitly allowed.
nodes.title: Implement and Manage a Firewall on End-User Devices

nodes.description: Implement and manage a firewall on servers, where supported. Example implementations include a virtual firewall, operating system firewall, or a third-party firewall agent.
nodes.title: Implement and Manage a Firewall on Servers

nodes.description: Configure automatic session locking on enterprise assets after a defined period of inactivity. For general purpose operating systems, the period must not exceed 15 minutes. For mobile end-user devices, the period must not exceed 2 minutes.
nodes.title: Configure Automatic Session Locking on Enterprise Assets

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a documented secure configuration process for network devices. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process for Network

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a documented secure configuration process for enterprise assets (end-user devices, including portable and mobile, non-computing/IoT devices, and servers) and software (operating systems and applications). Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Secure Configuration Process

nodes.name: Data Protection
nodes.description: Develop processes and technical controls to identify, classify, securely handle, retain, and dispose of data.
Log sensitive data access, including modification and disposal.
nodes.title: Log Sensitive Data Access

nodes.description: Implement an automated tool, such as a host-based Data Loss Prevention (DLP) tool to identify all sensitive data stored, processed, or transmitted through enterprise assets, including those located onsite or at a remote service provider, and update the enterprise’s  data inventory.
nodes.title: Deploy a Data Loss Prevention Solution

nodes.description: Segment data processing and storage based on the sensitivity of the data. Do not process sensitive data on enterprise assets intended for lower sensitivity data.
nodes.title: Segment Data Processing and Storage Based on Sensitivity

nodes.description: Encrypt sensitive data at rest on servers, applications, and databases. Storage-layer encryption, also known as server-side encryption, meets the minimum requirement of this Safeguard. Additional encryption methods may include application-layer encryption, also known as client-side encryption, where access to the data storage device(s) does not permit access to the plain-text data.
nodes.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data at Rest

nodes.description: Encrypt sensitive data in transit. Example implementations can include: Transport Layer Security (TLS) and Open Secure Shell (OpenSSH).
nodes.title: Encrypt Sensitive Data in Transit

nodes.description: Encrypt data on removable media.
nodes.title: Encrypt Data on Removable Media

nodes.description: Document data flows. Data flow documentation includes service provider data flows and should be based on the enterprise’s data management process. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Document Data Flows

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an overall data classification scheme for the enterprise. Enterprises may use labels, such as “Sensitive, ” “Confidential, ” and “Public, ” and classify their data according to those labels. Review and update the classification scheme annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Data Classification Scheme

nodes.description: Encrypt data on end-user devices containing sensitive data. Example implementations can include: Windows BitLocker®, Apple FileVault®, Linux® dm-crypt.
nodes.title: Encrypt Data on End-User Devices

nodes.description: Securely dispose of data as outlined in the enterprise’s documented data management process. Ensure the disposal process and method are commensurate with the data sensitivity.
nodes.title: Securely Dispose of Data

nodes.description: Retain data according to the enterprise’s documented data management process. Data retention must include both minimum and maximum timelines.
nodes.title: Enforce Data Retention

nodes.description: Configure data access control lists based on a user’s need to know. Apply data access control lists, also known as access permissions, to local and remote file systems, databases, and applications.
nodes.title: Configure Data Access Control Lists

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a data inventory based on the enterprise’s data management process. Inventory sensitive data, at a minimum. Review and update inventory annually, at a minimum, with a priority on sensitive data.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Data Inventory

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a documented data management process. In the process, address data sensitivity, data owner, handling of data, data retention limits, and disposal requirements, based on sensitivity and retention standards for the enterprise. Review and update documentation annually, or when significant enterprise changes occur that could impact this Safeguard.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Data Management Process

nodes.name: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
nodes.description: Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all software on the network so that only authorized software is installed and can execute.

Use technical controls, such as digital signatures and version control, to ensure that only authorized scripts, such as specific .ps1, and .py files are allowed to execute. Block unauthorized scripts from executing. Reassess bi-annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Allowlist Authorized Scripts

nodes.description: Use technical controls to ensure that only authorized software libraries, such as specific .dll, .ocx, and .so files, are allowed to load into a system process. Block unauthorized libraries from loading into a system process. Reassess bi-annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Allowlist Authorized Libraries

nodes.description: Use technical controls, such as application allowlisting, to ensure that only authorized software can execute or be accessed. Reassess bi-annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Allowlist Authorized Software

nodes.description: Utilize software inventory tools, when possible, throughout the enterprise to automate the discovery and documentation of installed software.
nodes.title: Utilize Automated Software Inventory Tools

nodes.description: Ensure that unauthorized software is either removed from use on enterprise assets or receives a documented exception. Review monthly, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Address Unauthorized Software

nodes.description: Ensure that only currently supported software is designated as authorized in the software inventory for enterprise assets. If software is unsupported, yet necessary for the fulfillment of the enterprise’s mission, document an exception detailing mitigating controls and residual risk acceptance. For any unsupported software without an exception documentation, designate as unauthorized. Review the software list to verify software support at least monthly, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Ensure Authorized Software is Currently Supported

nodes.description: Establish and maintain a detailed inventory of all licensed software installed on enterprise assets. The software inventory must document the title, publisher, initial install/use date, and business purpose for each entry; where appropriate, include the Uniform Resource Locator (URL), app store(s), version(s), deployment mechanism, decommission date, and number of licenses. Review and update the software inventory bi-annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain a Software Inventory

nodes.name: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
nodes.description: Actively manage (inventory, track, and correct) all enterprise assets connected to the infrastructure physically, virtually, remotely, and within cloud environments.
Use a passive discovery tool to identify assets connected to the enterprise’s network. Review and use scans to update the enterprise’s asset inventory at least weekly, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Use a Passive Asset Discovery Tool

nodes.description: Use DHCP logging on all DHCP servers or Internet Protocol (IP) address management tools to update the enterprise’s asset inventory. Review and use logs to update the enterprise’s asset inventory weekly, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Use Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) Logging to Update

nodes.description: Utilize an active discovery tool to identify assets connected to the enterprise’s network. Configure the active discovery tool to execute daily, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Utilize an Active Discovery Tool

nodes.description: Ensure that a process exists to address unauthorized assets on a weekly basis. The enterprise may choose to remove the asset from the network, deny the asset from connecting remotely to the network, or quarantine the asset.
nodes.title: Address Unauthorized Assets

nodes.description: Establish and maintain an accurate, detailed, and up-to-date inventory of all enterprise assets with the potential to store or process data, to include: end-user devices (including portable and mobile), network devices, non-computing/IoT devices, and servers. Ensure the inventory records the network address (if static), hardware address, machine name, enterprise asset owner, department for each asset, and whether the asset has been approved to connect to the network. For mobile end-user devices, MDM type tools can support this process, where appropriate. This inventory includes assets connected to the infrastructure physically, virtually, remotely, and those within cloud environments. Additionally, it includes assets that are regularly connected to the enterprise’s network infrastructure, even if they are not under control of the enterprise. Review and update the inventory of all enterprise assets bi-annually, or more frequently.
nodes.title: Establish and Maintain Detailed Enterprise Asset Inventory

nodes.name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework 2.0
nodes.description: Framework for managing cybersecurity risks

nodes.name: RECOVER
nodes.description: Assets and operations affected by a cybersecurity incident are restored

nodes.name: Incident Recovery Communication
nodes.description: Restoration activities are coordinated with internal and external parties
Public updates on incident recovery are shared using approved methods and messaging
nodes.example: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures for recovering from a data breach incident

nodes.description: Recovery activities and progress in restoring operational capabilities are communicated to designated internal and external stakeholders
nodes.example: Securely share recovery information, including restoration progress, consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

nodes.name: Incident Recovery Plan Execution
nodes.description: Restoration activities are performed to ensure operational availability of systems and services affected by cybersecurity incidents
The end of incident recovery is declared based on criteria, and incident-related documentation is completed
nodes.example: Prepare an after-action report that documents the incident itself, the response and recovery actions taken, and lessons learned

nodes.description: The integrity of restored assets is verified, systems and services are restored, and normal operating status is confirmed
nodes.example: Check restored assets for indicators of compromise and remediation of root causes of the incident before production use

nodes.description: Critical mission functions and cybersecurity risk management are considered to establish post-incident operational norms
nodes.example: Use business impact and system categorization records (including service delivery objectives) to validate that essential services are restored in the appropriate order

nodes.description: The integrity of backups and other restoration assets is verified before using them for restoration
nodes.example: Check restoration assets for indicators of compromise, file corruption, and other integrity issues before use

nodes.description: Recovery actions are selected, scoped, prioritized, and performed
nodes.example: Select recovery actions based on the criteria defined in the incident response plan and available resources

nodes.description: The recovery portion of the incident response plan is executed once initiated from the incident response process
nodes.example: Begin recovery procedures during or after incident response processes

nodes.name: RESPOND
nodes.description: Actions regarding a detected cybersecurity incident are taken

nodes.name: Incident Mitigation
nodes.description: Activities are performed to prevent expansion of an event and mitigate its effects
Incidents are eradicated
nodes.example: Cybersecurity technologies and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform eradication actions

nodes.description: Incidents are contained
nodes.example: Cybersecurity technologies (e.g., antivirus software) and cybersecurity features of other technologies (e.g., operating systems, network infrastructure devices) automatically perform containment actions

nodes.name: Incident Response Reporting and Communication
nodes.description: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders as required by laws, regulations, or policies
Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders
nodes.example: Securely share information consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

nodes.description: Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents
nodes.example: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures after discovering a data breach incident, including notifying affected customers

nodes.name: Incident Analysis
nodes.description: Investigations are conducted to ensure effective response and support forensics and recovery activities
An incident's magnitude is estimated and validated
nodes.example: Review other potential targets of the incident to search for indicators of compromise and evidence of persistence

nodes.description: Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved
nodes.example: Collect, preserve, and safeguard the integrity of all pertinent incident data and metadata (e.g., data source, date/time of collection) based on evidence preservation and chain-of-custody procedures

nodes.description: Actions performed during an investigation are recorded, and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved
nodes.example: Require each incident responder and others (e.g., system administrators, cybersecurity engineers) who perform incident response tasks to record their actions and make the record immutable

nodes.description: Analysis is performed to establish what has taken place during an incident and the root cause of the incident
nodes.example: Determine the sequence of events that occurred during the incident and which assets and resources were involved in each event

nodes.name: Incident Management
nodes.description: Responses to detected cybersecurity incidents are managed
The criteria for initiating incident recovery are applied
nodes.example: Apply incident recovery criteria to known and assumed characteristics of the incident to determine whether incident recovery processes should be initiated

nodes.description: Incidents are escalated or elevated as needed
nodes.example: Track and validate the status of all ongoing incidents

nodes.description: Incidents are categorized and prioritized
nodes.example: Further review and categorize incidents based on the type of incident (e.g., data breach, ransomware, DDoS, account compromise)

nodes.description: Incident reports are triaged and validated
nodes.example: Preliminarily review incident reports to confirm that they are cybersecurity-related and necessitate incident response activities

nodes.description: The incident response plan is executed in coordination with relevant third parties once an incident is declared
nodes.example: Detection technologies automatically report confirmed incidents

nodes.name: DETECT
nodes.description: Possible cybersecurity attacks and compromises are found and analyzed

nodes.name: Adverse Event Analysis
nodes.description: Anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events are analyzed to characterize the events and detect cybersecurity incidents
Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria
nodes.example: Apply incident criteria to known and assumed characteristics of activity in order to determine whether an incident should be declared

nodes.description: Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis
nodes.example: Securely provide cyber threat intelligence feeds to detection technologies, processes, and personnel

nodes.description: Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools
nodes.example: Use cybersecurity software to generate alerts and provide them to the security operations center (SOC), incident responders, and incident response tools

nodes.description: The estimated impact and scope of adverse events are understood
nodes.example: Use SIEMs or other tools to estimate impact and scope, and review and refine the estimates

nodes.description: Information is correlated from multiple sources
nodes.example: Constantly transfer log data generated by other sources to a relatively small number of log servers

nodes.description: Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities
nodes.example: Use security information and event management (SIEM) or other tools to continuously monitor log events for known malicious and suspicious activity

nodes.name: Continuous Monitoring
nodes.description: Assets are monitored to find anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events
Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor email, web, file sharing, collaboration services, and other common attack vectors to detect malware, phishing, data leaks and exfiltration, and other adverse events

nodes.description: External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor remote and onsite administration and maintenance activities that external providers perform on organizational systems

nodes.description: Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Use behavior analytics software to detect anomalous user activity to mitigate insider threats

nodes.description: The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor logs from physical access control systems (e.g., badge readers) to find unusual access patterns (e.g., deviations from the norm) and failed access attempts

nodes.description: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events
nodes.example: Monitor DNS, BGP, and other network services for adverse events

nodes.name: PROTECT
nodes.description: Safeguards to manage the organization's cybersecurity risks are used

nodes.name: Technology Infrastructure Resilience
nodes.description: Security architectures are managed with the organization's risk strategy to protect asset confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and organizational resilience
Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained
nodes.example: Monitor usage of storage, power, compute, network bandwidth, and other resources

nodes.description: Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations
nodes.example: Avoid single points of failure in systems and infrastructure

nodes.description: The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats
nodes.example: Protect organizational equipment from known environmental threats, such as flooding, fire, wind, and excessive heat and humidity

nodes.description: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage
nodes.example: Logically segment organization networks and cloud-based platforms according to trust boundaries and platform types (e.g., IT, IoT, OT, mobile, guests), and permit required communications only between segments

nodes.name: Platform Security
nodes.description: The hardware, software (e.g., firmware, operating systems, applications), and services of physical and virtual platforms are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect their confidentiality, integrity, and availability
Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle
nodes.example: Protect all components of organization-developed software from tampering and unauthorized access

nodes.description: Installation and execution of unauthorized software are prevented
nodes.example: When risk warrants it, restrict software execution to permitted products only or deny the execution of prohibited and unauthorized software

nodes.description: Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring
nodes.example: Configure all operating systems, applications, and services (including cloud-based services) to generate log records

nodes.description: Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
nodes.example: Replace hardware when it lacks needed security capabilities or when it cannot support software with needed security capabilities

nodes.description: Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk
nodes.example: Perform routine and emergency patching within the timeframes specified in the vulnerability management plan

nodes.description: Configuration management practices are established and applied
nodes.example: Establish, test, deploy, and maintain hardened baselines that enforce the organization's cybersecurity policies and provide only essential capabilities (i.e., principle of least functionality)

nodes.name: Data Security
nodes.description: Data are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information
Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested
nodes.example: Continuously back up critical data in near-real-time, and back up other data frequently at agreed-upon schedules

nodes.description: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use are protected
nodes.example: Remove data that must remain confidential (e.g., from processors and memory) as soon as it is no longer needed

nodes.description: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit are protected
nodes.example: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of network communications

nodes.description: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest are protected
nodes.example: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of stored data in files, databases, virtual machine disk images, container images, and other resources

nodes.name: Awareness and Training
nodes.description: The organization's personnel are provided with cybersecurity awareness and training so that they can perform their cybersecurity-related tasks
Individuals in specialized roles are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
nodes.example: Identify the specialized roles within the organization that require additional cybersecurity training, such as physical and cybersecurity personnel, finance personnel, senior leadership, and anyone with access to business-critical data

nodes.description: Personnel are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind
nodes.example: Provide basic cybersecurity awareness and training to employees, contractors, partners, suppliers, and all other users of the organization's non-public resources

nodes.name: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.description: Access to physical and logical assets is limited to authorized users, services, and hardware and  managed commensurate with the assessed risk of unauthorized access
Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk
nodes.example: Use security guards, security cameras, locked entrances, alarm systems, and other physical controls to monitor facilities and restrict access

nodes.description: Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
nodes.example: Review logical and physical access privileges periodically and whenever someone changes roles or leaves the organization, and promptly rescind privileges that are no longer needed

nodes.description: Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified
nodes.example: Protect identity assertions that are used to convey authentication and user information through single sign-on systems

nodes.description: Users, services, and hardware are authenticated
nodes.example: Require multifactor authentication

nodes.description: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions
nodes.example: Verify a person's claimed identity at enrollment time using government-issued identity credentials (e.g., passport, visa, driver's license)

nodes.description: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization
nodes.example: Initiate requests for new access or additional access for employees, contractors, and others, and track, review, and fulfill the requests, with permission from system or data owners when needed

nodes.name: IDENTIFY
nodes.description: The organization's current cybersecurity risks are understood

nodes.name: Improvement
nodes.description: Improvements to organizational cybersecurity risk management processes, procedures and activities are identified across all CSF Functions
Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved
nodes.example: Establish contingency plans (e.g., incident response, business continuity, disaster recovery) for responding to and recovering from adverse events that can interfere with operations, expose confidential information, or otherwise endanger the organization's mission and viability

nodes.description: Improvements are identified from execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities
nodes.example: Conduct collaborative lessons learned sessions with suppliers

nodes.description: Improvements are identified from security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties
nodes.example: Identify improvements for future incident response activities based on findings from incident response assessments (e.g., tabletop exercises and simulations, tests, internal reviews, independent audits)

nodes.description: Improvements are identified from evaluations
nodes.example: Perform self-assessments of critical services that take current threats and TTPs into consideration

nodes.name: Risk Assessment
nodes.description: The cybersecurity risk to the organization, assets, and individuals is understood by the organization
Critical suppliers are assessed prior to acquisition
nodes.example: Conduct supplier risk assessments against business and applicable cybersecurity requirements, including the supply chain

nodes.description: The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use
nodes.example: Assess the authenticity and cybersecurity of critical technology products and services prior to acquisition and use

nodes.description: Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established
nodes.example: Conduct vulnerability information sharing between the organization and its suppliers following the rules and protocols defined in contracts

nodes.description: Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, recorded, and tracked
nodes.example: Implement and follow procedures for the formal documentation, review, testing, and approval of proposed changes and requested exceptions

nodes.description: Risk responses are chosen, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated
nodes.example: Apply the vulnerability management plan's criteria for deciding whether to accept, transfer, mitigate, or avoid risk

nodes.description: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to understand inherent risk and inform risk response prioritization
nodes.example: Develop threat models to better understand risks to the data and identify appropriate risk responses

nodes.description: Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded
nodes.example: Business leaders and cybersecurity risk management practitioners work together to estimate the likelihood and impact of risk scenarios and record them in risk registers

nodes.description: Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded
nodes.example: Use cyber threat intelligence to maintain awareness of the types of threat actors likely to target the organization and the TTPs they are likely to use

nodes.description: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources
nodes.example: Configure cybersecurity tools and technologies with detection or response capabilities to securely ingest cyber threat intelligence feeds

nodes.description: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded
nodes.example: Use vulnerability management technologies to identify unpatched and misconfigured software

nodes.name: Asset Management
nodes.description: Assets (e.g., data, hardware, software, systems, facilities, services, people) that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance to organizational objectives and the organization's risk strategy
Systems, hardware, software, services, and data are managed throughout their life cycles
nodes.example: Integrate cybersecurity considerations throughout the life cycles of systems, hardware, software, and services

nodes.description: Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain a list of the designated data types of interest (e.g., personally identifiable information, protected health information, financial account numbers, organization intellectual property, operational technology data)

nodes.description: Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact on the mission
nodes.example: Define criteria for prioritizing each class of assets

nodes.description: Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained
nodes.example: Inventory all external services used by the organization, including third-party infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), platform-as-a-service (PaaS), and software-as-a-service (SaaS) offerings; APIs; and other externally hosted application services

nodes.description: Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows within the organization's wired and wireless networks

nodes.description: Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain inventories for all types of software and services, including commercial-off-the-shelf, open-source, custom applications, API services, and cloud-based applications and services

nodes.description: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained
nodes.example: Maintain inventories for all types of hardware, including IT, IoT, OT, and mobile devices

nodes.name: GOVERN
nodes.description: The organization's cybersecurity risk management strategy, expectations, and policy are established, communicated, and monitored

nodes.name: Cybersecurity Supply Chain Risk Management
nodes.description: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, managed, monitored, and improved by organizational stakeholders
Cybersecurity supply chain risk management plans include provisions for activities that occur after the conclusion of a partnership or service agreement
nodes.example: Establish processes for terminating critical relationships under both normal and adverse circumstances

nodes.description: Supply chain security practices are integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management programs, and their performance is monitored throughout the technology product and service life cycle
nodes.example: Policies and procedures require provenance records for all acquired technology products and services

nodes.description: Relevant suppliers and other third parties are included in incident planning, response, and recovery activities
nodes.example: Define and use rules and protocols for reporting incident response and recovery activities and the status between the organization and its suppliers

nodes.description: The risks posed by a supplier, their products and services, and other third parties are understood, recorded, prioritized, assessed, responded to, and monitored over the course of the relationship
nodes.example: Adjust assessment formats and frequencies based on the third party's reputation and the criticality of the products or services they provide

nodes.description: Planning and due diligence are performed to reduce risks before entering into formal supplier or other third-party relationships
nodes.example: Perform thorough due diligence on prospective suppliers that is consistent with procurement planning and commensurate with the level of risk, criticality, and complexity of each supplier relationship

nodes.description: Requirements to address cybersecurity risks in supply chains are established, prioritized, and integrated into contracts and other types of agreements with suppliers and other relevant third parties
nodes.example: Establish security requirements for suppliers, products, and services commensurate with their criticality level and potential impact if compromised

nodes.description: Suppliers are known and prioritized by criticality
nodes.example: Develop criteria for supplier criticality based on, for example, the sensitivity of data processed or possessed by suppliers, the degree of access to the organization's systems, and the importance of the products or services to the organization's mission

nodes.description: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes
nodes.example: Identify areas of alignment and overlap with cybersecurity and enterprise risk management

nodes.description: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established, communicated, and coordinated internally and externally
nodes.example: Identify one or more specific roles or positions that will be responsible and accountable for planning, resourcing, and executing cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities

nodes.description: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
nodes.example: Establish a strategy that expresses the objectives of the cybersecurity supply chain risk management program

nodes.name: Oversight
nodes.description: Results of organization-wide cybersecurity risk management activities and performance are used to inform, improve, and adjust the risk management strategy
Organizational cybersecurity risk management performance is evaluated and reviewed for adjustments needed
nodes.example: Review key performance indicators (KPIs) to ensure that organization-wide policies and procedures achieve objectives

nodes.description: The cybersecurity risk management strategy is reviewed and adjusted to ensure coverage of organizational requirements and risks
nodes.example: Review audit findings to confirm whether the existing cybersecurity strategy has ensured compliance with internal and external requirements

nodes.description: Cybersecurity risk management strategy outcomes are reviewed to inform and adjust strategy and direction
nodes.example: Measure how well the risk management strategy and risk results have helped leaders make decisions and achieve organizational objectives

nodes.name: Policy
nodes.description: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established, communicated, and enforced
Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is reviewed, updated, communicated, and enforced to reflect changes in requirements, threats, technology, and organizational mission
nodes.example: Update policy based on periodic reviews of cybersecurity risk management results to ensure that policy and supporting processes and procedures adequately maintain risk at an acceptable level

nodes.description: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is established based on organizational context, cybersecurity strategy, and priorities and is communicated and enforced
nodes.example: Create, disseminate, and maintain an understandable, usable risk management policy with statements of management intent, expectations, and direction

nodes.name: Roles, Responsibilities, and Authorities
nodes.description: Cybersecurity roles, responsibilities, and authorities to foster accountability, performance assessment, and continuous improvement are established and communicated
Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices
nodes.example: Integrate cybersecurity risk management considerations into human resources processes (e.g., personnel screening, onboarding, change notification, offboarding)

nodes.description: Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with the cybersecurity risk strategy, roles, responsibilities, and policies
nodes.example: Conduct periodic management reviews to ensure that those given cybersecurity risk management responsibilities have the necessary authority

nodes.description: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced
nodes.example: Document risk management roles and responsibilities in policy

nodes.description: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving
nodes.example: Leaders (e.g., directors) agree on their roles and responsibilities in developing, implementing, and assessing the organization's cybersecurity strategy

nodes.name: Risk Management Strategy
nodes.description: The organization's priorities, constraints, risk tolerance and appetite statements, and assumptions are established, communicated, and used to support operational risk decisions
Strategic opportunities (i.e., positive risks) are characterized and are included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions
nodes.example: Define and communicate guidance and methods for identifying opportunities and including them in risk discussions (e.g., strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats [SWOT] analysis)

nodes.description: A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated
nodes.example: Establish criteria for using a quantitative approach to cybersecurity risk analysis, and specify probability and exposure formulas

nodes.description: Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties
nodes.example: Determine how to update senior executives, directors, and management on the organization's cybersecurity posture at agreed-upon intervals

nodes.description: Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated
nodes.example: Specify criteria for accepting and avoiding cybersecurity risk for various classifications of data

nodes.description: Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes
nodes.example: Aggregate and manage cybersecurity risks alongside other enterprise risks (e.g., compliance, financial, operational, regulatory, reputational, safety)

nodes.description: Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are established, communicated, and maintained
nodes.example: Determine and communicate risk appetite statements that convey expectations about the appropriate level of risk for the organization

nodes.description: Risk management objectives are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders
nodes.example: Update near-term and long-term cybersecurity risk management objectives as part of annual strategic planning and when major changes occur

nodes.name: Organizational Context
nodes.description: The circumstances - mission, stakeholder expectations, dependencies, and legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements - surrounding the organization's cybersecurity risk management decisions are understood
Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are understood and communicated
nodes.example: Create an inventory of the organization's dependencies on external resources (e.g., facilities, cloud-based hosting providers) and their relationships to organizational assets and business functions

nodes.description: Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that external stakeholders depend on or expect from the organization are understood and communicated
nodes.example: Establish criteria for determining the criticality of capabilities and services as viewed by internal and external stakeholders

nodes.description: Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity - including privacy and civil liberties obligations - are understood and managed
nodes.example: Determine a process to track and manage legal and regulatory requirements regarding protection of individuals' information (e.g., Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, California Consumer Privacy Act, General Data Protection Regulation)

nodes.description: Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered
nodes.example: Identify relevant internal stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., performance and risk expectations of officers, directors, and advisors; cultural expectations of employees)

nodes.description: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management
nodes.example: Share the organization's mission (e.g., through vision and mission statements, marketing, and service strategies) to provide a basis for identifying risks that may impede that mission
